owl:Ontology.dc:creator: Aitor Corchero (aitor.corchero@eurecat.org)
Pierre Bourreau (pbourreau@nobatek.com)
Richard Chbeir (richard.chbeir@univ-pau.fr)
Yudith Cardinale (ycardinale@usb.ve)
owl:Ontology.dc:description:
Features of interest are real world representations of the building. They comprise building infrastructure and the corresponding building elements (mechanical and electrical elements, furniture, etc.).
To adapt the SSN ontology to the building domain, the ifcOwl which is the web semantic ontology for the Industry Foundation Class (IFC), has been incorporated. This semantic model permits to link the proposed ontology with the BIM notation.
To do so, the feature of interest class of SSN has been linked (hierarchically) with the concepts Ifc:Building, Ifc:BuildingElement, and Ifc:BuildingAppliance. Each building pertains to a specific type (through the "hasType" semantic relation). Considering their infrastructure, each building contains several real work zones (Ifc:Zone). These zones can be rooms, floors, desk, etc. Moreover, different views of a building can be used: infrastructure to represent the floors, rooms...; but also an electric view (to represent the electric appliances inside the building), fluid view (to represent the possible flow of water/gas inside the building), etc. Over these abstracted views, the different building elements are represented: building systems ("Flow Instruments", "Protective Devices", “Unitary Control Elements"), sensors and building appliance for monitoring and controlling the building, occupants’ devices, etc. The features of interest representation of the building are performed using standard building modelling (IFC and BIM). Moreover, this semantic model ensures the information compatibility and sharing with these models. A part of this, the building infrastructure and their corresponding zones and devices are modelled and linked with their corresponding information, aspect that facilitates data querying based on the corresponding feature of interests.
owl:Ontology.dc:title: Hit2Gap Ontology-Building Infrastructure
owl:Ontology.owl:versionInfo: This current version includes the initial version of the semantic model based on the diagrams generated.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Optional description, provided for exchanging informative comments.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: description_IfcRoot

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Assignment of a globally unique identifier within the entire software world.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: globalId_IfcRoot

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Optional name for use by the participating software systems or users. For some subtypes of IfcRoot the insertion of the Name attribute may be required. This would be enforced by a where rule.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: name_IfcRoot

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Datum elevation relative to sea level.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: refElevation_IfcSite

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: World Latitude at reference point (most likely defined in legal description). Defined as integer values for degrees, minutes, seconds, and, optionally, millionths of seconds with respect to the world geodetic system WGS84. Latitudes are measured relative to the geodetic equator, north of the equator by positive values - from 0 till +90, south of the equator by negative values - from 0 till -90.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: refLatitude_IfcSite

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment:
World Longitude at reference point (most likely defined in legal description). Defined as integer values for degrees, minutes, seconds, and, optionally, millionths of seconds with respect to the world geodetic system WGS84.
Longitudes are measured relative to the geodetic zero meridian, nominally the same as the Greenwich prime meridian: longitudes west of the zero meridian have positive values - from 0 till +180, longitudes east of the zero meridian have negative values - from 0 till -180.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: refLongitude_IfcSite
made by sensor
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Relation between an Observation and the Sensor which made the Observation.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Relation between a Sensor and an ObservableProperty that it is capable of sensing.
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Relation between a Sensor and an ObservableProperty that it is capable of sensing.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: A relation between some aspect of an entity and a Property.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: for property
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: A relation between some aspect of an entity and a Property.
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:example: For example, from a Sensor to the properties it can observe; from an Actuator to the properties it can act on; from a Deployment to the properties it was installed to observe or act on; from a SystemCapability to the Property the capability is described for.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Relation between an ObservableProperty and the Sensor able to observe it.
owl:ObjectProperty.skos:definition: Relation between an ObservableProperty and the Sensor able to observe it.

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: Data proeprty to define the external ID regaring the time series stored in Mondas.
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: externalID

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Building Appliances represent the static and mobile appliances inside the building. Several devices and IFC specific devices has been categorised and included.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: BuildingAppliance

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Meter is a device which measures the integral, with respect to time, of the power in an electric circuit.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Meter

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Mobile Building Appliances represent mobile appliances inside the building.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: MobileBuildingAppliance

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Monitoring is a static building appliance for monitoring and controlling the building, occupants’ devices, etc.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Monitoring

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Static Building Appliances represent static appliances inside the building. Several devices and IFC specific devices has been categorised and included.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: StaticBuildingAppliance

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Wearable is a building appliance representing a wereable device such as smartwatches and smartphones.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Wearable

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Air represents air as a physical medium to produce energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Air

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An AirHandlingUnit is a device used to regulate and circulate air as part of a heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) system.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: AirHandlingUnit

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Arid represents an observation of the arid climate in a specific time.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Arid

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Balcony is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing a balcony.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Balcony

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Bathroom is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing a bathroom.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Bathroom

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Cafeteria is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing a cafeteria.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Cafeteria

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Canteen is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing a canteen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Canteen

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A ChilledBeam is a type of convection HVAC system designed to heat or cool large buildings. Pipes of water are passed through a "beam" (a heat exchanger) either integrated into standard suspended ceiling systems or suspended a short distance from the ceiling of a room.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ChilledBeams

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: CirculationArea is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing a circulation area.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: CirculationArea

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Climate represents an observation of the climate in a specific time.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Climate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: ConferenceRoom is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing a conference room.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ConferenceRoom

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Continental represents an observation of the continental climate in a specific time.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Continental

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Desk is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing a desk.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Desk

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An ElectricHeater represents an electrical device that converts electric current to heat.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ElectricHeater

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A FanCoilUnit is a simple device consisting of a heating or cooling heat exchanger or 'coil' and fan. It is part of an HVAC system found in residential, commercial, and industrial buildings. A fan coil unit is a diverse device sometimes using ductwork, and is used to control the temperature in the space where it is installed, or serve multiple spaces. It is controlled either by a manual on/off switch or by a thermostat, which controls the throughput of water to the heat exchanger using a control valve and/or the fan speed.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: FanCoilUnit

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Floor is an instance of a story in the building.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Floor

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Ground represents a ground floor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Ground

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A HeatPump is a device that transfers heat energy from a source of heat to a destination called a "heat sink". Heat pumps are designed to move thermal energy in the opposite direction of spontaneous heat transfer by absorbing heat from a cold space and releasing it to a warmer one. A heat pump uses a small amount of external power to accomplish the work of transferring energy from the heat source to the heat sink.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: HeatPump

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hemisphere denotes the hemisphere of a feature.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Hemisphere

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Kitchen is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing a kitchen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Kitchen

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: LampType determines the type of the lamp.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: LampType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Radiation represents radiation as a physical medium to produce energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Light

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Office is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing an office.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Office

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil represents oil as a physical medium to produce energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: OpenSpace is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing an open space.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: OpenSpace

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Orientation determines the orientation of the building.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Orientation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: PhysicalMedium represents the physical element that is used to produce energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: PhysicalMedium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Polar represents an observation of the polar climate in a specific time.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Polar

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: RestRoom is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing a rest room.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: RestRoom

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Room is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing a Room.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Room

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A SteamPlant represents a plant using steam prime movers to drive electric generating apparatus.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: SteamPlant

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Sunterranean represents a subterranean floor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Subterranean

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Temperate represents an observation of the temperate climate in a specific time.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Temperate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Toilets is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing toilets.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Toilets

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Tropical represents an observation of the tropical climate in a specific time.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Tropical

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Water represents water as a physical medium to produce energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Water

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A WaterPlant represents a plant operated by pressure transmitted through a pipe by a liquid, such as water or oil.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: WaterPlant

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: WetArea is an instance of IfcSpace in the building representing a wet area.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: WetArea

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
FeatureOfInterest is an extension of ssn#FeatureOfInterest defined in SSN. We have extended it and made them equivalents.
A feature is an abstraction of real world phenomena (thing, person, event, etc). The thing whose property is being estimated or calculated in the course of an Observation to arrive at a Result or whose property is being manipulated by an Actuator, or which is being sampled or transformed in an act of Sampling.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: FeatureOfInterest

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: This observation specifies a particular location of a mobile building appliance in a specific time.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: MobileBuildingApplianceLocationObservation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Observation is an extension of ssn#Observation defined in SSN. We have extended it and made them equivalents.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Observation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An inverter and a rectifier perform opposite functions in electronic circuits. Both act as electric power converters; a rectifier changes current from alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC), while an inverter converts DC to AC.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: AcDcConverter

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: BiomassBranch represents a branch which produces energy by burning wood and other organic matter.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: BiomassBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A branch is an energy consumer or producer that has a specific energy load over a certain time span (called energyprofile).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Branch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A Branch Controller is the manager of branch operations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: BranchController

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The Branch Switch is responsible of turning on/off a branch.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: BranchSwitch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: CHPBranch represents a combined heat and power (CHP) branch, which uses a heat engine or power station to generate electricity and useful heat at the same time.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: CHPBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A ConductingEquipment concept, represents the parts of the power system that are designed to carry current. This concepts is from the Common Information Model (CIM), which is a widely accepted energy information model being part of the IEC 61970 standards.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ConductingEquipment

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A CIMRectifierInverter concept, represents the parts of the power system that are designed to inverte/rectify current. An inverter and a rectifier perform opposite functions in electronic circuits. Both act as electric power converters; a rectifier changes current from alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC), while an inverter converts DC to AC. This concepts is from the Common Information Model (CIM), which is a widely accepted energy information model being part of the IEC 61970 standards.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: CIMRectifierInverter

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: CoalBranch represents a branch which uses coal to generate energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: CoalBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An inverter and a rectifier perform opposite functions in electronic circuits. Both act as electric power converters; a rectifier changes current from alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC), while an inverter converts DC to AC.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Converter

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: DERBranch represents a distributed energy resource branch, which consists of renewable or nonrenewable energy sources.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: DERBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A DieselGenerator is the combination of a diesel engine with an electric generator (often an alternator) to generate electrical energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: DieselGenerator

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An Electrical Load Branch is an electrical component or branch that consumes electric power. It mainly consists of electrical appliance components.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ELBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Energy storage systems play an essential role in stabilizing the power system, improving the quality of power supply, and achieving power peak shaving. The energy storage branch consists mainly of the energy storage device (e.g., flywheel, super-capacitor) and a converter.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ESBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: FuelCellBranch is an electrochemical energy conversion device. It produces electricity from external supplies of fuel (on the anode side) and oxidant (on the cathode side). These reacts in the presence of an electrolyte.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: FuelCellBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: GasBranch represents a branch which uses gas to generate energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: GasBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: GeoThermalBranch represents a branch which produces geothermal energy. Geothermal resources are reservoirs of hot water that exist at varying temperatures and depths below the Earth's surface.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: GeoThermalBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: HydroPowerBranch represents a branch which produces energy derived from the energy of falling water or fast running water.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: HydroPowerBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An InfraBranch represents an infrastructure branch, where each has its own Branch Switch and Branch Controller.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: InfraBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An inverter and a rectifier perform opposite functions in electronic circuits. Both act as electric power converters; a rectifier changes current from alternating current (AC) to direct current (DC), while an inverter converts DC to AC. An inverter can be a Monophasic or a Triphasic.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Inverter

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: MicroCHPBranch represents a micro combined heat and power (CHP) branch, which uses a heat engine or power station to generate electricity and useful heat at the same time.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: MicroCHPBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A microgrid is based on several branches that link the building infrastructure with the generated building renewable flows, non-renewable flows and the different building systems linked with that flows.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Microgrid

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: MicroturbinesBranch represents a branch with a type of combustion turbine that produces both heat and electricity on a relatively small scale.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: MicroturbinesBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An Inverter can be a Monophasic or a Triphasic.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: MonophasicInverter

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: NonRenewableDERBranch represents the non-renewable distributed energy resource branches.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: NonRenewableDERBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: NuclearBranch represents a branch, which uses nuclear energy to generate energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: NuclearBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: OilBranch represents a branch which uses oil to generate energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: OilBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A PhotovoltaicBranch represents a photovoltaic power system that directly converts solar energy into electricity.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: PhotovoltaicBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: ReciprocatingBranch is an engine that utilizes one or more pressure-driven pistons in order to convert back-and-forth motion into a rotating motion. The most common form of reciprocating engine used to generate electricity is the diesel engine, which is used in combination with an electric generator to form a diesel generator.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ReciprocatingBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: RenewableDERBranch represents the renewable distributed energy resource branches.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: RenewableDERBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: SmallWindPowerBranch represents a branch that uses air flow through wind turbines to mechanically generate electric power.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: SmallWindPowerBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A SolarHybridBranch represents a power system that the transforms energy from sunlight into electricity, either directly using photovoltaics (PV), indirectly using concentrated solar power, or a combination.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: SolarHybridBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A SolarPowerBranch represents a power system that directly converts solar energy into electricity.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: SolarPowerBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A StirlingBranch represents a heat engine that operates by cyclic compression and expansion of air or other gas (the working fluid) at different temperatures, such that there is a net conversion of heat energy to mechanical work. More specifically, the Stirling engine is a closed-cycle regenerative heat engine with a permanently gaseous working fluid.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: StirlingBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An Inverter can be a Monophasic or a Triphasic.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: TriphasicInverter

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: WindHybridBranch represents the use of air flow through wind turbines to mechanically power generators for electric power.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: WindHybridBranch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An actuator is a mechanical device for moving or controlling a mechanism or system. An actuator takes energy, usually created by air, electricity, or liquid, and converts that into some kind of motion.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcActuator

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcAirToAirHeatRecovery defines the occurrence of any air-to-air heat recovery device; common information about air-to-air heat recovery device types is handled by IfcAirToAirHeatRecoveryType. The IfcAirToAirHeatRecoveryType (if present) may establish the common type name, usage (predefined type), properties, materials, ports, composition, assignments, and representations. The IfcAirToAirHeatRecoveryType is attached using the IfcRelDefinesByType objectified relationship and is accessible by the IsTypedBy inverse attribute.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcAirToAirHeatRecover

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An alarm is a device that signals the existence of a condition or situation that is outside the boundaries of normal expectation or that activates such a device. Alarms include the provision of break glass buttons and manual pull boxes that are used to activate alarms.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcAlarm

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An audio-visual appliance is a device that displays, captures, transmits, or receives audio or video. Audio-visual appliances may be fixed in place or may be able to be moved from one space to another. They may require an electrical supply that may be supplied either by an electrical circuit or provided from a local battery source. Audio-visual appliances may be connected to data circuits including specialist circuits for audio visual purposes only.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcAudioVisualAppliance

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcBoiler defines the occurrence of any boiler; common information about boiler types is handled by IfcBoilerType. The IfcBoilerType (if present) may establish the common type name, usage (predefined type), properties, materials, ports, composition, assignments, and representations. The IfcBoilerType is attached using the IfcRelDefinesByType objectified relationship and is accessible by the IsTypedBy inverse attribute.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcBoiler

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A burner is a device that converts fuel into heat through combustion. It includes gas, oil, and wood burners.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcBurner

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A chiller is a device used to remove heat from a liquid via a vapor-compression or absorption refrigeration cycle to cool a fluid, typically water or a mixture of water and glycol. The chilled fluid is then used to cool and dehumidify air in a building.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcChiller

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A coil is a device used to provide heat transfer between non-mixing media. A common example is a cooling coil, which utilizes a finned coil in which circulates chilled water, antifreeze, or refrigerant that is used to remove heat from air moving across the surface of the coil. A coil may be used either for heating or cooling purposes by placing a series of tubes (the coil) carrying a heating or cooling fluid into an airstream. The coil may be constructed from tubes bundled in a serpentine form or from finned tubes that give a extended heat transfer surface
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcCoil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A communications appliance transmits and receives electronic or digital information as data or sound. Communication appliances may be fixed in place or may be able to be moved from one space to another. Communication appliances require an electrical supply that may be supplied either by an electrical circuit or provided from a local battery source.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcCommunicationAppliance

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An IfcCompressor is a device that compresses a fluid typically used in a refrigeration circuit.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcCompressor

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A condenser is a device that is used to dissipate heat, typically by condensing a substance such as a refrigerant from its gaseous to its liquid state.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcCondenser

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A cooling tower is a device which rejects heat to ambient air by circulating a fluid such as water through it to reduce its temperature by partial evaporation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcCoolingTower

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcDamper defines the occurrence of any damper; common information about damper types is handled by IfcDamperType. The IfcDamperType (if present) may establish the common type name, usage (predefined type), properties, materials, ports, composition, assignments, and representations. The IfcDamperType is attached using the IfcRelDefinesByType objectified relationship and is accessible by the IsTypedBy inverse attribute.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcDamper

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcElectricAppliance defines the occurrence of any electric appliance; common information about electric appliance types is handled by IfcElectricApplianceType. The IfcElectricApplianceType (if present) may establish the common type name, usage (predefined type), properties, materials, ports, composition, assignments, and representations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcElectricAppliance

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An electric flow storage device is a device in which electrical energy is stored and from which energy may be progressively released.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcElectricFlowStorageDevice

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An electric generator is an engine that is a machine for converting mechanical energy into electrical energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcElectricGenerator

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An electric motor is an engine that is a machine for converting electrical energy into mechanical energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcElectricMotor

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An engine is a device that converts fuel into mechanical energy through combustion.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcEngine

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An evaporative cooler is a device that cools air by saturating it with water vapor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcEvaporativeCooler

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An evaporator is a device in which a liquid refrigerent is vaporized and absorbs heat from the surrounding fluid.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcEvaporator

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcFan defines the occurrence of any fan; common information about fan types is handled by IfcFanType. The IfcFanType (if present) may establish the common type name, usage (predefined type), properties, materials, ports, composition, assignments, and representations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcFan

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A fire suppression terminal has the purpose of delivering a fluid (gas or liquid) that will suppress a fire. A fire suppression terminal provides for all forms of sprinkler, spreader and other form of terminal that is connected to a pipework system and intended to act in the role of suppressing a fire.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcFireSuppressionTerminal

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A heat exchanger is a device used to provide heat transfer between non-mixing media such as plate and shell and tube heat exchangers. IfcHeatExchanger is commonly used on water-side distribution systems to recover energy from a liquid to another liquid (typically water-based), whereas IfcAirToAirHeatRecovery is commonly used on air-side distribution systems to recover energy from a gas to a gas (usually air).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcHeatExchanger

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A humidifier is a device that adds moisture into the air.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcHumidifier

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An interceptor is a device designed and installed in order to separate and retain deleterious, hazardous or undesirable matter while permitting normal sewage or liquids to discharge into a collection system by gravity.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcInterceptor

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A lamp is an artificial light source such as a light bulb or tube.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcLamp

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcOutlet defines the occurrence of any outlet; common information about outlet types is handled by IfcOutletType. The IfcOutletType (if present) may establish the common type name, usage (predefined type), properties, materials, ports, composition, assignments, and representations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcOutlet

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcPump defines the occurrence of any pump; common information about pump types is handled by IfcPumpType. The IfcPumpType (if present) may establish the common type name, usage (predefined type), properties, materials, ports, composition, assignments, and representations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcPump

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcSanitaryTerminal defines the occurrence of any sanitary terminal; common information about sanitary terminal types is handled by IfcSanitaryTerminalType. The IfcSanitaryTerminalType (if present) may establish the common type name, usage (predefined type), properties, materials, ports, composition, assignments, and representations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSanitaryTerminal

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A sensor is a device that measures a physical quantity and converts it into a signal which can be read by an observer or by an instrument.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSensor

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A solar device converts solar radiation into other energy such as electric current or thermal energy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSolarDevice

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Space heaters utilize a combination of radiation and/or natural convection using a heating source such as electricity, steam or hot water to heat a limited space or area. Examples of space heaters include radiators, convectors, baseboard and finned-tube heaters.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSpaceHeater

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A stack terminal is placed at the top of a ventilating stack (such as to prevent ingress by birds or rainwater) or rainwater pipe (to act as a collector or hopper for discharge from guttering).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcStackTerminal

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A tank is a vessel or container in which a fluid or gas is stored for later use.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcTank

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A transformer is an inductive stationary device that transfers electrical energy from one circuit to another. IfcTransformer is used to transform electric power; conversion of electric signals for other purposes is handled at other entities: IfcController converts arbitrary signals, IfcAudioVisualAppliance converts signals for audio or video streams, and IfcCommunicationsAppliance converts signals for data or other communications usage.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcTransformer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A unitary control element combines a number of control components into a single product, such as a thermostat or humidistat. A unitary control element provides a housing for an aggregation of control or electrical distribution elements that, in combination, perform a singular (unitary) purpose. Each item in the aggregation may have its own geometric representation and location.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcUnitaryControlElement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcValve defines the occurrence of any valve; common information about valve types is handled by IfcValveType. The IfcValveType (if present) may establish the common type name, usage (predefined type), properties, materials, ports, composition, assignments, and representations. The IfcValveType is attached using the IfcRelDefinesByType objectified relationship and is accessible by the IsTypedBy inverse attribute.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcValve

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A vibration isolator is a device used to minimize the effects of vibration transmissibility in a building.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcVibrationIsolator

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcWasteTerminal defines the occurrence of any waste terminal; common information about waste terminal types is handled by IfcWasteTerminalType. The IfcWasteTerminalType (if present) may establish the common type name, usage (predefined type), properties, materials, ports, composition, assignments, and representations. The IfcWasteTerminalType is attached using the IfcRelDefinesByType objectified relationship and is accessible by the IsTypedBy inverse attribute.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcWasteTerminal

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcActuatorType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcActuator defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcActuatorType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcAirToAirHeatRecoveryType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcAirToAirHeatRecovery defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcAirToAirHeatRecoverType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcAlarmType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcAlarm defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcAlarmType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An IfcBeam is a horizontal, or nearly horizontal, structural member. It represents such a member from an architectural point of view. It is not required to be load bearing.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcBeam

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcBoilerType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcBoiler defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcBoilerType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A building represents a structure that provides shelter for its occupants or contents and stands in one place. The building is also used to provide a basic element within the spatial structure hierarchy for the components of a building project (together with site, storey, and space).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcBuilding

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
The building element comprises all elements that are primarily part of the construction of a building, i.e., its structural and space separating system.
EXAMPLEs of building elements are walls, beams, or doors, they are all physically existent and tangible things
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcBuildingElement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
The building storey has an elevation and typically represents a (nearly) horizontal aggregation of spaces that are vertically bound.
A storey is (if specified) associated to a building. A storey may span over several connected storeys. Therefore storey complex provides for a collection of storeys included in a building. A storey can also be decomposed in (horizontal) parts, where each part defines a partial storey. This is defined by the composition type attribute of the supertype IfcSpatialStructureElements which is interpreted as follow:
COMPLEX = building storey complex ELEMENT = building storey PARTIAL = partial building storey
EXAMPLE: In split level houses, a storey is split into two or more partial storeys, each with a different elevation. It can be handled by defining a storey, which includes two or more partial storeys with the individual elevations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcBuildingStorey

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcChillerType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcChiller defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcChillerType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Chimneys are typically vertical, or as near as vertical, parts of the construction of a building and part of the building fabric. Often constructed by pre-cast or insitu concrete, today seldom by bricks.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcChimmey

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcCoilType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcCoil defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcCoilType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An IfcColumn is a vertical structural member which often is aligned with a structural grid intersection. It represents a vertical, or nearly vertical, structural member from an architectural point of view. It is not required to be load bearing.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcColumn

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcCompressorType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcCompressor defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcCompressorType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcCondenserType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcCondenser defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcCondenserType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcCoolingTowerType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcCoolingTower defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcCoolingTowerType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
A covering is an element which covers some part of another element and is fully dependent on that other element. The IfcCovering defines the occurrence of a covering type, that (if given) is expressed by the IfcCoveringType.
EXAMPLEs include wall claddings, floorings and suspended ceilings as well as finish trim and base molding.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcCovering

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Exterior wall of a building which is an assembly of components, hung from the edge of the floor/roof structure rather than bearing on a floor
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcCurtainWall

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcDamperType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcDamper defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcDamperType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A distribution circuit is a partition of a distribution system that is conditionally switched such as an electrical circuit.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcDistributionCircuit

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcDistributionControlElement defines occurrence elements of a building automation control system that are used to impart control over elements of a distribution system.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcDistributionControlElement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The IfcDistributionElement defines the occurrence of any HVAC, electrical, sanitary or other element within a distribution system. Common information about distribution element types (or styles) is handled by subtypes of IfcDistributionElementType. The IfcDistributionElementType (if present) may establish the common type name, usage (or predefined) type, common material, common set of properties and common shape representations (using IfcRepresentationMap).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcDistributionElement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
The distribution element IfcDistributionFlowElement defines occurrence elements of a distribution system that facilitate the distribution of energy or matter, such as air, water or power.
EXAMPLEs of distribution flow elements are ducts, pipes, wires, fittings, equipment, etc.
The IfcDistributionFlowElement defines the occurrence of a distribution element within the spatial context of a project.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcDistributionFlowElement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
A distribution system is a network designed to receive, store, maintain, distribute, or control the flow of a distribution media. A common example is a heating hot water system that consists of a pump, a tank, and an interconnected piping system for distributing hot water to terminals. The group IfcDistributionSystem defines the occurrence of a specialized system for use within the context of building services. Important functionalities for the description of a distribution system are derived from existing IFC entities:
From IfcSystem it inherits the ability to couple the distribution system via IfcRelServicesBuildings to one or more IfcSpatialElement subtypes as necessary.
From IfcGroup it inherits the inverse attribute IsGroupedBy, pointing to the relationship entity IfcRelAssignsToGroup. This allows to group distribution elements (instances of IfcDistributionElement subtypes), and in special cases ports directly (instances of IfcDistributionPort).
From IfcObject it inherits the inverse attribute IsDecomposedBy pointing to the relationship entity IfcRelAggregates. It provides the hierarchy between the separate (partial) distribution systems. For example, an electrical main circuit may be aggregated into branch circuits.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcDistributionSystem

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
The door is a building element that is predominately used to provide controlled access for people and goods. It includes constructions with hinged, pivoted, sliding, and additionally revolving and folding operations. A door consists of a lining and one or several panels, properties concerning the lining and panel are defined by the IfcDoorLiningProperties and the IfcDoorPanelProperties.
The door entity, IfcDoor, defines a particular occurrence of a door inserted in the spatial context of a project
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcDoor

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcElectricApplianceType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcElectricAppliance defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcElectricApplianceType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcElectricFlowStorageDeviceType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcElectricFlowStorageDevice defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcElectricFlowStorageDeviceType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcElectricGeneratorType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcElectricGenerator defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcElectricGeneratorType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcElectricMotorType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcElectricMotor defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcElectricMotorType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An element is a generalization of all components that make up an AEC product. Elements are physically existent objects, although they might be void elements, such as holes. Elements either remain permanently in the AEC product, or only temporarily, as formwork does. Elements can be either assembled on site or pre-manufactured and built in on site.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcElement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An element component is a representation for minor items included in, added to or connecting to or between elements, which usually are not of interest from the overall building structure viewpoint. However, these small parts may have vital and load carrying functions within the construction. These items do not provide any actual space boundaries. Typical examples of IfcElementComponents include different kinds of fasteners and various accessories.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcElementComponent

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcEnergyConversionDevice defines the occurrence of a device used to perform energy conversion or heat transfer and typically participates in a flow distribution system. Its type is defined by IfcEnergyConversionDeviceType or its subtypes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcEnergyConversionDevice

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcEvaporativeCoolerType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcEvaporativeCooler defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcEvaporativeCoolerType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcEvaporatorType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcEvaporator defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcEvaporatorType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcFanType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcFan defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcFanType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcFireSuppressionTerminalType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcFireSuppressionTerminal defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcFireSuppressionTerminalType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcFlowController defines the occurrence of elements of a distribution system that are used to regulate flow through a distribution system. Examples include dampers, valves, switches, and relays. Its type is defined by IfcFlowControllerType or subtypes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcFlowController

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcFlowMovingDevice

IfcFlowMovingDevice defines the occurrence of an apparatus used to distribute, circulate, or perform conveyance of fluids, including liquids and gases (such as a pump or fan), and typically participates in a flow distribution system. Its type is defined by IfcFlowMovingDeviceType or its subtypes.

The distribution flow element IfcFlowStorageDevice defines the occurrence of a device that participates in a distribution system and is used for temporary storage (such as a tank). Its type is defined by IfcFlowStorageDeviceType or its subtypes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcFlowStorageDevice

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The distribution flow element IfcFlowTerminal defines the occurrence of a permanently attached element that acts as a terminus or beginning of a distribution system (e.g., air outlet, drain, water closet, sink, etc.). A terminal is typically a point at which a system interfaces with an external environment. Its type is defined by IfcFlowTerminalType or its subtypes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcFlowTerminal

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The distribution flow element IfcFlowTreatmentDevice defines the occurrence of a device typically used to remove unwanted matter from a fluid, either liquid or gas, and typically participates in a flow distribution system. Its type is defined by IfcFlowTreatmentDeviceType or its subtypes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcFlowTreatmentDevice

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcFooting is a part of the foundation of a structure that spreads and transmits the load directly to the soil.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcFooting

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcHeatExchangerType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcHeatExchanger defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcHeatExchangerType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcHumidifierType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcHumiidifier defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcHumidifierType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcLampType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcLamp defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcLampType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An IfcMember is a structural member designed to carry loads between or beyond points of support. It is not required to be load bearing. The location of the member (being horizontal, vertical or sloped) is not relevant to its definition (in contrary to IfcBeam and IfcColumn).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcMember

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcOutletType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcOutlet defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcOutletType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A pile is a slender timber, concrete, or steel structural element, driven, jetted, or otherwise embedded on end in the ground for the purpose of supporting a load. A pile is also characterized as deep foundation, where the loads are transfered to deeper subsurface layers.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcPile

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An IfcPlate is a planar and often flat part with constant thickness. A plate can be a structural part carrying loads between or beyond points of support, however it is not required to be load bearing. The location of the plate (being horizontal, vertical or sloped) is not relevant to its definition (in contrary to IfcWall and IfcSlab (as floor slab)).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcPlate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcPumpType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcPump defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcPumpType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The railing is a frame assembly adjacent to human circulation spaces and at some space boundaries where it is used in lieu of walls or to compliment walls. Designed to aid humans, either as an optional physical support, or to prevent injury by falling.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcRailing

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
An vertical passageway which provides a human circulation link between one floor level and another floor level at a different elevation. It may include a landing as an intermediate floor slab. A ramp normally does not include steps (stepped ramps are out of scope for this IFC Release).
The ramp is a container entity that aggregates all components of the ramp, it represents. The aggregation is handled via the IfcRelAggregates relationship, relating an IfcRamp with the related flights (IfcRampFlight) and landings (IfcSlab with type 'Landing'). Railings belonging to the ramp may be included into the aggregation as IfcRailing.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcRamp

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An IfcRampFlight is an aggregated part of an IfcRamp realized through the IfcRelAggregates relationship, the ramp flight is therefore included in the set of IfcRelAggregates.RelatedObjects. An IfcRampFlight connects the floor slab of zero to two different storeys (or partial storeys or landings) within a building.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcRampFlight

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The IfcRoof is a description of the total roof. It acts as a container entity, that aggregates all components of the roof, it represents. The aggregation is handled via the IfcRelAggregates relationship, relating a roof (IfcRoof) with the related roof entities, like slabs (IfcSlab), rafters and purlins (IfcBeam), or other (included) roofs, such as dormers (IfcRoof).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcRoof

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcSanitaryTerminalType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcSanitaryTerminal defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSanitaryTerminalType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcSensorType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcSensor defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSensorType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Shading devices are purpose built devices to protect from the sunlight, from natural light, or screening them from view. Shading devices can form part of the facade or can be mounted inside the building, they can be fixed or operable.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcShadingDevice

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
A defined area of land, possibly covered with water, on which the project construction is to be completed. A site may be used to erect building(s) or other AEC products.
A site (IfcSite) may include a definition of the single geographic reference point for this site (global position using Longitude, Latitude and Elevation) for the project. This definition may specify an exact global position of the origin of the local placement of the IfcSite in geospatial terms or it may specify an approximate position intended for informational purposes only.
The geometrical placement of the site, defined by the IfcLocalPlacement, shall be always relative to the spatial structure element, in which this site is included, or absolute, i.e. to the world coordinate system, as established by the geometric representation context of the project. The world coordinate system, established at the IfcProject.RepresentationContexts, may include a definition of the true north within the XY plane of the world coordinate system, if provided, it can be obtained at IfcGeometricRepresentationContext.TrueNorth.
A project may span over several connected or disconnected sites. Therefore site complex provides for a collection of sites included in a project. A site can also be decomposed in parts, where each part defines a site section. This is defined by the composition type attribute of the supertype IfcSpatialStructureElements which is interpreted as follow:
COMPLEX = site complex ELEMENT = site PARTIAL = site section
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
The IfcSlab defines the occuurence of any slab, common information about slab types (or styles) is handled by IfcSlabType. The IfcSlabType (if present) may establish the common type name, usage (or predefined) type, common set of properties, common material layer set, and common shape representations (using IfcRepresentationMap). The IfcSlabType is attached using the IfcRelDefinedByType.RelatingType objectified relationship and is accessible by the inverse IsDefinedBy attribute.
As an additional use agreement for standard slabs (i.e. slabs with constant thickness along the extrusion direction), the IfcSlabType should have a unique IfcMaterialLayerSet, that is referenced by the IfcMaterialLayerSetUsage assigned to all occurrences of this slab type.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSlab

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
A space represents an area or volume bounded actually or theoretically. Spaces are areas or volumes that provide for certain functions within a building.
A space is (if specified) associated to a building storey (or in case of exterior spaces to a site). A space may span over several connected spaces. Therefore a space group provides for a collection of spaces included in a storey. A space can also be decomposed in parts, where each part defines a partial space. This is defined by the composition type attribute of the supertype IfcSpatialStructureElement which is interpreted as follow:
COMPLEX = space group ELEMENT = space PARTIAL = partial space The following guidelines should apply for using the Name, Description, LongName and ObjectType attributes.
Name holds the unique name (or space number) from the plan. Description holds any additional information field the user may have specified, there are no further recommendations. LongName holds the full name of the space, it is often used in addition to the Name, if a number is assigned to the room, then the descriptive name is exchanged as LongName. ObjectType holds the space type, i.e. usually the functional category of the space.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSpace

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcSpaceHeaterType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcSpaceHeater defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSpaceHeaterType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
A spatial element is the generalization of all spatial elements that might be used to define a spatial structure or to define spatial zones.
a hierarchical spatial structure element as IfcSpatialStructureElement a spatial structure is a hiearchical decomposition of the project. That spatial structure is often used to provide a project structure to organize a building project.
A spatial project structure might define as many levels of decomposition as necessary for the building project. Elements within the spatial project structure are site, building, storey, and space a spatial zone as IfcSpatialZone a spatial zone is a non-hierarchical and potentially overlapping decomposition of the project under some functional consideration. a spatial zone might be used to represent a thermal zone, a lighting zone, a usable area zone. a spatial zone might have its independent placement and shape representation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSpatialElement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
A spatial structure element (IfcSpatialStructureElement) is the generalization of all spatial elements that might be used to define a spatial structure. That spatial structure is often used to provide a project structure to organize a building project.
A spatial project structure might define as many levels of decomposition as necessary for the building project. Elements within the spatial project structure are:
site as IfcSite building as IfcBuilding storey as IfcBuildingStorey space as IfcSpace
or aggregations or parts thereof. The composition type declares an element to be either an element itself, or an aggregation (complex) or a decomposition (part). The interpretation of these types is given at each subtype of IfcSpatialStructureElement.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSpatialStructureElement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
A spatial zone is a non-hierarchical and potentially overlapping decomposition of the project under some functional consideration. A spatial zone might be used to represent a thermal zone, a construction zone, a lighting zone, a usable area zone. A spatial zone might have its independent placement and shape representation.
NOTE The IfcSpatialZone is different to the IfcZone entity by allowing an own placement and shape representation, whereas IfcZone is only a grouping of IfcSpace's.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSpatialZone

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcStackTerminalType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcStackTerminal defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcStackTerminalType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A stair is a vertical passageway allowing occupants to walk (step) from one floor level to another floor level at a different elevation. It may include a landing as an intermediate floor slab.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcStair

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
Assembly of building components in a single "run" of stair steps (not interrupted by a landing). The stair steps and any stringers are included in this object. A winder is regarded as part of a stair flight.
An IfcStairFlight is normally aggregated by a stair (IfcStair) through the IfcRelAggregates relationship, the stair flight is then included in the set of IfcRelAggregates.RelatedObjects.
An IfcStairFlight normally connects the floor slab of zero to two different storeys (or partial storeys) within a building.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcStairFlight

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcTankType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcTank defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcTankType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcTransformerType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcTransformer defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcTransformerType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcUnitaryControlElementType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcUnitaryControlElement defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcUnitaryControlElementType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcValveType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcValve defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcValveType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcVibrationisolatorType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcVibrationisolator defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcVibrationIsolatorType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The wall represents a vertical construction that bounds or subdivides spaces. Wall are usually vertical, or nearly vertical, planar elements, often designed to bear structural loads. A wall is however not required to be load bearing.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcWall

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcWasteTerminalType is defined in IFC2X3. We made it equivalent to IfcWasteTerminal defined in IFC4.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcWasteTerminalType

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
The window is a building element that is predominately used to provide natural light and fresh air. It includes vertical and horizontal opening (e.g. skylights or light domes). It includes constructions with swinging, pivoting, sliding, or revolving panels and fixed panels. A window consists of a lining and one or several panels.
The IfcWindow defines a particular occurrence of a window inserted in the spatial context of a project.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcWindow

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
A zone (IfcZone) is an aggregation of spaces, partial spaces or other zones. Zone structures may not be hierarchical (in contrary to the spatial structure of a project - see IfcSpatialStructureElement), i.e. one individual IfcSpace may be associated with zero, one, or several IfcZone's. IfcSpace's are aggregated into an IfcZone by using the objectified relationship IfcRelAssignsToGroup as specified at the supertype IfcGroup.
NOTE Certain use cases may restrict the freedom of non hierarchical relationships. In some building service use cases the zone denotes a view based delimited volume for the purpose of analysis and calculation. This type of zone cannot overlap with respect to that analysis, but may overlap otherwise.
NOTE One of the purposes of a zone is to define a fire compartmentation. In this case it defines the geometric information about the fire compartment (through the contained spaces) and information, whether this compartment is ventilated or sprinkler protected. In addition the fire risk code and the hazard type can be added, the coding is normally defined within a national fire regulation. All that information is available within the relevant property sets. RECOMMENDATION In case of a zone denoting a (fire) compartment, the following types should be used, if applicable, as values of the ObjectType attribute:
FireCompartment - a zone of spaces, collected to represent a single fire compartment.
ElevatorShaft - a collection of spaces within an elevator, potentially going through many storeys.
RisingDuct
RunningDuct
Additional classifications of the IfcZone, as provided by a national classification system, can be assigned by using the IfcRelAssociatesClassification relationship.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcZone

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
Holds an identifier that is unique throughout the software world. This is also known as a Globally Unique Identifier (GUID) or Universal Unique Identifier (UUID) by the Open Group. The identifier is generated using an algorithm published by the Object Management Group. The algorithm is explained at the open group website. The Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC) function "CoCreateGuid", which is an implementation of the above algorithm, has been used by many IFC implementers to create an identifier.
An identifier is a unique 128-bit number. Since this identifier is required for all IFC object instances, it is desirable to compress the identifier size to reduce overhead. Beginning in IFC R1.5.1, IFC implementers agreed to compress the identifier down to 20 characters using an algorithm developed by IAI Implementers. This algorithm maps the identifier bits onto a base 85 digit encoded from the following character set:
0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz!#$%&^|*+,-./:;<=>?~`@_
An index (0-84) into this character set string determines the "value" for each character (e.g. "A" has a value of 10, "@" has a value of 83, etc.). Note that all characters are case-sensitive. In order to prevent possible problems with some parsers, implementers have agreed not to use the "/*" and "*/" character combinations in the identifier string and instead to use "\*" and "*\".
The implementation of the compression algorithm has changed in IFC R2x in order to prevent conflicts with special characters in the ISO 10303-21 exchange file and the W3C XML file (such as '<*', '*>', '<' and '>'). Using 64 characters for the base rather than 85, the resulting compressed string now needs 22 characters. The encoding of the base 64 character set is shown below:
1 2 3 4 5 6 0123456789012345678901234567890123456789012345678901234567890123 "0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz_$";
The following code example in C is given as a guideline for creating the base 64 compressed strings and for mapping the previous base 85 strings to the base 64 strings. This code is provided "as-is" with no support or guarantee of suitability provided by the IAI. Use of the code example is at the sole risk of the user.
CreateGuid_64.h CreateGuid_64.c The resulting string is a fixed 22 character length string to be exchanged within the IFC exchange file structure.
HISTORY: New type in IFC R1.5.1.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcGloballyUniqueId

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
The IfcRoot is the most abstract and root class for all IFC entity definitions that roots in the kernel or in subsequent layers of the IFC object model. It is therefore the common supertype all all IFC entities, beside those defined in an IFC resource schema. All entities that are subtypes of IfcRoot can be used independently, whereas resource schema entities, that are not subtypes of IfcRoot, are not supposed to be independent entities.
The IfcRoot assigns the globally unique ID, and the ownership and history information to the entity. In addition it may provide for a name and a description about the concepts.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcRoot

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The gml:posList property is defined for all elements of LineString.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: LineString

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The gml:posList property is defined for all elements of LinearRing
owl:Class.rdfs:label: LinearRing

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A point contains a single coordinate pair. The coordinate pair contains a latitude value and a longitude value in that order. The preferred serialization of this uses a space to separate the two values.
The gml:pos property is defined for all elements of Point
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Point

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A polygon contains at least four coordinate pairs. Each pair contains a latitude value and a longitude value in that order. The preferred serialization of this uses a space to separate the two values. Pairs are separated from each other by a space. The last coordinate pair must be identical to the first.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Polygon

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: _Feature is taken from the GeoRSS Feature Model. The model provides a general feature property which can be used to characterize any appropriate content as a geographic feature. Specific subproperties such as <where> associate the discerned feature with one of a limited number of geometry types which provide a numerical representation for analysis and visualization. Other subproperties describe additional commonly used feature attributes such as feature name and feature type.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: _Feature

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: GeoRSS feature model allows the description of rectangles, points, lines, and polygons as geometric representation properties of discerned geographic features. Simple Features' geometric representations consist of point and multipoint, curve (a.k.a. line) and multicurve, surface (polygon) and multisurface.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: _Geometry

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: It enables compact representation of an interval corresponding to a single element in a date-time description (i.e. a specified year, month, week, day, hour, minute, second).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: DateTimeInterval

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A temporal entity with zero extent or duration.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Instant

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The Result of an Observation, Actuation, or act of Sampling. To store an observation's simple result value one can use the hasSimpleResult property.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Result
owl:Class.skos:example: The value 20 as the height of a certain tree together with the unit, e.g., Meter.

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Device, agent (including humans), or software (simulation) involved in, or implementing, a (Sensing) Procedure. Sensors respond to a stimulus, e.g., a change in the environment, or input data composed from the results of prior Observations, and generate a Result. Sensors can be hosted by Platforms.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Sensor

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: System is a unit of abstraction for pieces of infrastructure that implements Procedures. A System may have components, its subsystems, which are other systems.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: System

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: The Northern hemisphere - used for location of buildings and elements
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Northern

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: The southern hemisphere. Used for localization of buildings
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: Southern

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Gas represents gas as a physical medium to produce energy.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Gas

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: Steam represents steam as a physical medium to produce energy.
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Steam
